001package squidpony.squidgrid.gui.gdx;
002
003import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Color;
004import com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils;
005import squidpony.squidmath.DiverRNG;
006import squidpony.squidmath.MathExtras;
007import squidpony.squidmath.NumberTools;
008import com.github.tommyettinger.anim8.PaletteReducer;
009
010import static squidpony.squidgrid.gui.gdx.SColor.*;
011
012/**
013 * Pre-made FloatFilter classes that you can use to filter colors without producing extra Color objects.
014 * <br>
015 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 7/22/2018.
016 */
017public final class FloatFilters {
018    private FloatFilters() {
019        // don't build me!
020    }
021
022    /**
023     * Wraps the functionality of {@link SColor#toEditedFloat(float, float, float, float, float)} so it can be called as
024     * a FloatFilter, adding values to hue, saturation, and value (clamping saturation and value and wrapping hue).
025     * Hue is in the 0.0 to 1.0 range, as SquidLib handles it, instead of libGDX's 0 to 360 range.
026     */
027    public static class HSVFilter extends FloatFilter {
028        public float hueAddend, saturationAddend, valueAddend;
029
030        public HSVFilter(float saturation, float value) {
031            this(0f, saturation, value);
032        }
033
034        public HSVFilter(float hueAdd, float saturationAdd, float valueAdd) {
035            hueAddend = hueAdd;
036            saturationAddend = saturationAdd;
037            valueAddend = valueAdd;
038        }
039
040        /**
041         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
042         *
043         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
044         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
045         */
046        @Override
047        public float alter(float color) {
048            return SColor.toEditedFloat(color, hueAddend, saturationAddend, valueAddend, 0f);
049        }
050    }
051
052    /**
053     * Changes all colors this alters to have the same hue as, and a closer saturation to, a target color given in the
054     * constructor, as well as optionally multiplying saturation of the result and/or adding lightness/value. A good
055     * example usage of this is to make a sepia-tone effect with
056     * {@code new FloatFilters.ColorizeFilter(SColor.CLOVE_BROWN, 0.6f, 0.0f)}.
057     */
058    public static class ColorizeFilter extends FloatFilter {
059        public float targetCb, targetCr, lumaAddend;
060
061        public ColorizeFilter(float color) {
062            this(color, 1f, 0f);
063        }
064
065        public ColorizeFilter(Color color) {
066            this(color.toFloatBits(), 1f, 0f);
067        }
068
069        public ColorizeFilter(Color color, float chromaMul, float lumaAdd) {
070            this(color.toFloatBits(), chromaMul, lumaAdd);
071        }
072
073        public ColorizeFilter(float color, float chromaMul, float lumaAdd) {
074            targetCb = SColor.chromaBOfFloat(color) * chromaMul;
075            targetCr = SColor.chromaROfFloat(color) * chromaMul;
076            lumaAddend = lumaAdd;
077        }
078
079        /**
080         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
081         *
082         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
083         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
084         */
085        @Override
086        public float alter(float color) {
087            final int bits = NumberTools.floatToIntBits(color);
088            return SColor.floatGetYCbCr((bits & 0x000000ff) * (0x1.010102p-8f  * 0.299f) +
089                    (bits & 0x0000ff00) * (0x1.010102p-16f * 0.587f) +
090                    (bits & 0x00ff0000) * (0x1.010102p-24f * 0.114f),
091                    targetCb, targetCr,
092                    ((bits & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0x1.020408p-8f);
093        }
094    }
095
096    /**
097     * A FloatFilter that alters primarily-red and primarily-green colors so they can be more easily be distinguished by
098     * people with at least some forms of red-green color-blindness (deuteranopia should be handled well, protanopia
099     * very well, and tritanopia may not benefit at all). Causes reds to be darkened and greens to be lightened if the
100     * other of the pair is not present in similar quantities (which is the case for yellows and blues).
101     */
102    public static class DistinctRedGreenFilter extends FloatFilter {
103        /**
104         * Constructs a DistinctRedGreenFilter. This class is a simple wrapper around a function that doesn't need
105         * member variables, so there should be little overhead with this filter.
106         */
107        public DistinctRedGreenFilter() {
108        }
109
110        /**
111         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
112         *
113         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
114         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
115         */
116        @Override
117        public float alter(float color) {
118//            final int bits = NumberTools.floatToIntBits(color),
119//                    r = bits & 0xFF, g = bits >>> 8 & 0xFF, b = bits >>> 16 & 0xFF, a = bits >>> 24,
120//                    diff = g - r;
121//            if (diff > 101)
122//                return floatGet(Math.min(1f, 0x1.010102p-16f * r * (203 + (diff >> 1))),
123//                        Math.min(1f, 0x1.010102p-16f * g * (228 + (diff >> 1))),
124//                        Math.min(1f, 0x1.010102p-16f * b * (203 + (diff >> 1))),
125//                        0x1.010102p-8f * a);
126//            else if (diff < -75)
127//                return floatGet(Math.min(1f, 0x1.010102p-16f * r * (152 - diff)),
128//                        Math.min(1f, 0x1.010102p-16f * g * (177 - diff)),
129//                        Math.min(1f, 0x1.010102p-16f * b * (177 - diff)),
130//                        0x1.010102p-8f * a);
131//            else
132//                return color;
133            final int bits = NumberTools.floatToIntBits(color);
134            final float opacity = (bits >>> 25) * 0.007874016f;
135            float luma = (
136                    (bits & 0x000000ff) * (0x1.010102p-8f * 0.299f) +
137                            (bits & 0x0000ff00) * (0x1.010102p-16f * 0.587f) +
138                            (bits & 0x00ff0000) * (0x1.010102p-24f * 0.114f));
139            float chromaB = (
140                    (bits & 0x000000ff) * (0x1.010102p-8f * -0.168736f) +
141                            (bits & 0x0000ff00) * (0x1.010102p-16f * -0.331264f) +
142                            (bits & 0x00ff0000) * (0x1.010102p-24f * 0.5f));
143            float chromaR = (
144                    (bits & 0x000000ff) * (0x1.010102p-8f * 0.5f) +
145                            (bits & 0x0000ff00) * (0x1.010102p-16f * -0.418688f) +
146                            (bits & 0x00ff0000) * (0x1.010102p-24f * -0.081312f));
147            if(chromaB < -0.05f)
148            {
149                float theta = NumberTools.atan2(chromaR, chromaB);
150                float dist = (float) Math.sqrt(chromaB * chromaB + chromaR * chromaR);
151                if(theta >= 0f)
152                {
153                    theta *= 0.5f;
154                    luma += theta * 0.15f;
155                    theta += 0.7853981633974483f;
156                }
157                else
158                {
159                    theta *= 0.4f;
160                    luma += theta * 0.225f;
161                    theta -= 0.9424778335276408f;
162                }
163                chromaR = MathUtils.sin(theta) * dist;
164                chromaB = MathUtils.cos(theta) * dist;
165            }
166            return floatGet(MathUtils.clamp(luma + chromaR * 1.402f, 0f, 1f),
167                    MathUtils.clamp(luma - chromaB * 0.344136f - chromaR * 0.714136f, 0f, 1f),
168                    MathUtils.clamp(luma + chromaB * 1.772f, 0f, 1f),
169                    opacity);
170
171        }
172    }
173
174    /**
175     * A FloatFilter that makes no changes to the colors given to it; useful as a default for when no filter is wanted.
176     */
177    public static class IdentityFilter extends FloatFilter {
178        /**
179         * Takes a packed float color and returns it un-edited.
180         *
181         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
182         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
183         */
184        @Override
185        public float alter(float color) {
186            return color;
187        }
188    }
189
190    /**
191     * A static constant of the one possible IdentityFilter, to avoid needing to make duplicates.
192     * IdentityFilter makes no changes to the colors given to it.
193     */
194    public static final IdentityFilter identityFilter = new IdentityFilter();
195
196    /**
197     * A FloatFilter that makes all colors given to it grayscale, using only their luma as calculated by
198     * {@link SColor#lumaOfFloat(float)} as the lightness (it does also preserve alpha transparency).
199     */
200    public static class GrayscaleFilter extends FloatFilter {
201        /**
202         * Takes a packed float color and produces a grayscale packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
203         * Uses the luma calculation from {@link SColor#lumaOfFloat(float)} instead of the value calculation from
204         * {@link SColor#valueOfFloat(float)}; luma tends to be more visually-accurate on modern monitors.
205         *
206         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
207         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
208         */
209        @Override
210        public float alter(float color) {
211            final int bits = NumberTools.floatToIntBits(color);
212            color = (bits & 0x000000ff) * (0x1.010102p-8f * 0.299f) +
213                    (bits & 0x0000ff00) * (0x1.010102p-16f * 0.587f) +
214                    (bits & 0x00ff0000) * (0x1.010102p-24f * 0.114f);
215            return floatGet(color, color, color, (bits >>> 25) * 0.007874016f);
216        }
217    }
218    
219    public static final GrayscaleFilter grayscaleFilter = new GrayscaleFilter();
220
221    /**
222     * Like {@link HSVFilter}, but edits its input colors in YCbCr color space, and multiplies rather than adds.
223     * Y is luma, and affects how bright the color is (luma 1 is white, luma 0 is black). Cb is Chroma(blue) amd Cr is
224     * Chroma(red), two inter-related channels that determine the hue and vividness of a specific color. When Cb and Cr
225     * are both 0, the color is grayscale. When Cb is 0.5 and Cr is -0.5, the color is blue unless Y is very high or
226     * low. When Cb is -0.5 and Cr is 0.5, the color is red with the same caveats re: Y. When Cb and Cr are both -0.5,
227     * the color is green (same caveats), and when both are 0.5, the color is purple. When Y is 0.5, Cb and Cr form a
228     * graph like this:
229     * <br>
230     * <img src="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/YCbCr-CbCr_Y50.png/240px-YCbCr-CbCr_Y50.png" />
231     * <br>
232     * Valid values for Cb and Cr are from -0.5 to 0.5 at the widest part of the range (it shrinks as Y approaches 0 or
233     * 1), but there aren't really invalid values here because this filter will clamp results with higher or lower
234     * channel values than a color can have. Each of yMul, cbMul, and crMul can have any float value, but yMul should be
235     * positive (unless you want this to only produce solid black). Similarly, cbMul and crMul will not produce
236     * meaningful results if they are very large (either positive or negative); it's recommended to use values between
237     * 0.0 and 1.0 for both if you want to desaturate colors or values somewhat greater than 1.0 to oversaturate them.
238     */
239    public static class YCbCrFilter extends FloatFilter {
240        public float yMul, cbMul, crMul;
241
242        public YCbCrFilter(float yMul) {
243            this(yMul, 1f, 1f);
244        }
245
246        public YCbCrFilter(float yMul, float cbMul, float crMul) {
247            this.yMul = yMul;
248            this.cbMul = cbMul;
249            this.crMul = crMul;
250        }
251
252        /**
253         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
254         *
255         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
256         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
257         */
258        @Override
259        public float alter(float color) {
260            final int bits = NumberTools.floatToIntBits(color);
261            final float opacity = (bits >>> 25) * 0.007874016f;
262            float luma = yMul * (
263                    (bits & 0x000000ff) * (0x1.010102p-8f * 0.299f) +
264                            (bits & 0x0000ff00) * (0x1.010102p-16f * 0.587f) +
265                            (bits & 0x00ff0000) * (0x1.010102p-24f * 0.114f));
266            final float chromaB = cbMul * (
267                    (bits & 0x000000ff) * (0x1.010102p-8f * -0.168736f) +
268                            (bits & 0x0000ff00) * (0x1.010102p-16f * -0.331264f) +
269                            (bits & 0x00ff0000) * (0x1.010102p-24f * 0.5f));
270            final float chromaR = crMul * (
271                    (bits & 0x000000ff) * (0x1.010102p-8f * 0.5f) +
272                            (bits & 0x0000ff00) * (0x1.010102p-16f * -0.418688f) +
273                            (bits & 0x00ff0000) * (0x1.010102p-24f * -0.081312f));
274            return floatGet(MathUtils.clamp(luma + chromaR * 1.402f, 0f, 1f),
275                    MathUtils.clamp(luma - chromaB * 0.344136f - chromaR * 0.714136f, 0f, 1f),
276                    MathUtils.clamp(luma + chromaB * 1.772f, 0f, 1f),
277                    opacity);
278        }
279    }
280
281    /**
282     * Like {@link YCbCrFilter}, but edits its input colors in YCoCg color space, or like {@link HSVFilter} except it
283     * doesn't add, it multiplies. Most of the time you should prefer {@link YCbCrFilter} as long as it isn't a
284     * performance bottleneck; this method is faster but less accurate. Y is luminance, ranging from 0 (dark) to 1
285     * (light), and affects how bright the color is, but isn't very accurate perceptually. Co is Chrominance(orange) and
286     * Cg is Chrominance(green) (both range from -0.5 to 0.5), two inter-related channels that determine the hue and
287     * vividness of a specific color. When Co and Cg are both 0, the color is grayscale. When Co is 0.5 and Cg is -0.5,
288     * the color is red unless Y is very high or low. When Co is -0.5 and Cg is 0.5, the color is cyan with the same
289     * caveats re: Y. When Co and Cg are both -0.5, the color is blue (same caveats), and when both are 0.5, the color
290     * is yellow.
291     * <br>
292     * Valid values for Co and Cg are from -0.5 to 0.5 at the widest part of the range (it shrinks as Y approaches 0 or
293     * 1), but there aren't really invalid values here because this filter will clamp results with higher or lower
294     * channel values than a color can have. Each of yMul, coMul, and cgMul can have any float value, but yMul should be
295     * positive (unless you want this to only produce solid black). Similarly, coMul and cgMul will not produce
296     * meaningful results if they are very large (either positive or negative); it's recommended to use values between
297     * 0.0 and 1.0 for both if you want to desaturate colors or values somewhat greater than 1.0 to oversaturate them.
298     */
299    public static class YCoCgFilter extends FloatFilter {
300        public float yMul, coMul, cgMul;
301
302        public YCoCgFilter(float luminanceMul, float orangeMul, float greenMul) {
303            this.yMul = luminanceMul;
304            this.coMul = orangeMul;
305            this.cgMul = greenMul;
306        }
307
308        /**
309         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
310         *
311         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
312         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
313         */
314        @Override
315        public float alter(float color) {
316            final int bits = NumberTools.floatToIntBits(color);
317            final float opacity = (bits >>> 25) * 0.007874016f;
318            final float y = yMul * (((bits & 0x000000ff) + ((bits & 0x0000ff00) >>> 7) + ((bits & 0x00ff0000) >>> 16)) * 0x1.010102p-10f);
319            final float co = coMul * (((bits & 0x000000ff) - ((bits & 0x00ff0000) >>> 16)) * 0x1.010102p-9f);
320            final float cg = cgMul * ((((bits & 0x0000ff00) >>> 7) - (bits & 0x000000ff) - ((bits & 0x00ff0000) >>> 16)) * 0x1.010102p-10f);
321
322            final float t = y - cg;
323            return floatGet(MathUtils.clamp(t + co, 0f, 1f),
324                    MathUtils.clamp(y + cg, 0f, 1f),
325                    MathUtils.clamp(t - co, 0f, 1f),
326                    opacity);
327        }
328    }
329
330    /**
331     * Like {@link YCbCrFilter} or  {@link YCoCgFilter}, but edits its input colors in YCwCm color space, which is very
332     * similar to YCoCg but has chroma/chrominance components that are useful aesthetically on their own. You may often
333     * prefer {@link YCbCrFilter} because it calculates lightness (luma) more precisely, but the Cb (blue-ness) and Cr
334     * (red-ness) components are less useful for some purposes individually. Y is luminance, ranging from 0 (dark) to 1
335     * (light), and affects how bright the color is, but isn't very accurate perceptually. Cw is Chroma(warm) and
336     * Cm is Chroma(mild) (both range from -1.0 to 1.0), two inter-related channels that determine the hue and vividness
337     * of a specific color. When Cw and Cm are both 0, the color is grayscale. When Cw is 1 and Cm is -1, the color
338     * is red or like red. When Cw is -1 and Cm is 1, the color is green or like green. When Cw and Cm are both -1, the
339     * color is blue or like blue, and when both are 1, the color is roughly yellow or brown (depending on Y).
340     * <br>
341     * Valid values for Cw and Cm are from -1.0 to 1.0, but there aren't really invalid values here because this filter
342     * will clamp results with higher or lower channel values than a color can have. Each of yMul, cwMul, and cmMul can
343     * have any float value, but yMul should be positive (unless you want this to only produce solid black). Similarly,
344     * cwMul and cmMul will not produce meaningful results if they are very large (either positive or negative); it's
345     * recommended to use values between 0.0 and 1.0 for both if you want to desaturate colors or values somewhat
346     * greater than 1.0 to oversaturate them. Unlike {@link YCbCrFilter} and {@link YCoCgFilter}, you can benefit from
347     * setting cwMul independently of the other chroma component, which can be used to emphasize warm vs. cool colors if
348     * cwMul is greater than 1.0, or to de-emphasize that comparison if it is between 0.0 and 1.0. A similar option is
349     * possible for cmMul, but it isn't as clear of an artistic convention; a high cmMul will separate green-and-yellow
350     * colors further from red-purple-and-blue colors. Also unlike the other YCC filters, this allows an additive change
351     * to Y, Cw, and Cm applied after the multiplicative change but before converting to RGB and clamping. This can be
352     * used to make all colors warmer or cooler (such as for volcano or frozen scenes) by adding or subtracting from Cw,
353     * for instance. It can also lighten or darken all colors by changing luma.
354     */
355    public static class YCwCmFilter extends FloatFilter {
356        public float yMul, cwMul, cmMul, yAdd, cwAdd, cmAdd;
357
358        public YCwCmFilter(float yMul, float cwMul, float cmMul) {
359            this(yMul, cwMul, cmMul, 0f, 0f, 0f);
360        }
361        public YCwCmFilter(float yMul, float cwMul, float cmMul, float yAdd, float cwAdd, float cmAdd) {
362            this.yMul = yMul;
363            this.cwMul = cwMul;
364            this.cmMul = cmMul;
365            this.yAdd = yAdd;
366            this.cwAdd = cwAdd;
367            this.cmAdd = cmAdd;
368        }
369
370        /**
371         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
372         *
373         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
374         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
375         */
376        @Override
377        public float alter(float color) {
378            final int bits = NumberTools.floatToIntBits(color);
379            final float opacity = (bits >>> 25) * 0.007874016f;
380            final float luma = yAdd + yMul * ((bits & 0xFF) * 0x3p-11f + (bits >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1p-9f + (bits >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1p-11f);
381            final float warm = (cwAdd + cwMul * (((bits & 0xFF) - (bits >>> 16 & 0xff)) * 0x1.010102p-8f));
382            final float mild = 0.5f * (cmAdd + cmMul * (((bits >>> 8 & 0xff) - (bits >>> 16 & 0xff)) * 0x1.010102p-8f));
383
384            return floatGet(MathUtils.clamp(luma + warm * 0.625f - mild, 0f, 1f),
385                    MathUtils.clamp(luma + mild - warm * 0.375f, 0f, 1f),
386                    MathUtils.clamp(luma - warm * 0.375f - mild, 0f, 1f),
387                    opacity);
388        }
389    }
390
391    /**
392     * A FloatFilter that chains together one or more FloatFilters one after the next, passing the float output of one
393     * as input to the next until the chain has all been called.
394     */
395    public static class ChainFilter extends FloatFilter {
396        public FloatFilter[] filters;
397
398        /**
399         * Takes a vararg or array of FloatFilter objects and produces a ChainFilter that will call all of them in order
400         * on any color given to this to alter.
401         * @param filters an array or vararg of FloatFilter objects; none can be null
402         */
403        public ChainFilter(FloatFilter... filters)
404        {
405            if(filters == null || filters.length == 0)
406                this.filters = new FloatFilter[]{new IdentityFilter()};
407            this.filters = filters;
408        }
409
410        /**
411         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
412         *
413         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
414         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
415         */
416        @Override
417        public float alter(float color) {
418            for (int i = 0; i < filters.length; i++) {
419                color = filters[i].alter(color);
420            }
421            return color;
422        }
423    }
424
425    /**
426     * A FloatFilter that linearly interpolates (lerps) any color it is given toward a specified color by a specified
427     * amount. Uses {@link SColor#lerpFloatColorsBlended(float, float, float)} to mix a requested color with the target
428     * color, and this means the alpha of the target color affects the amount of change instead of the resulting alpha. 
429     */
430    public static class LerpFilter extends FloatFilter {
431        public float target, amount;
432
433        /**
434         * Builds a LerpFilter with a Color (which will be converted to a packed float color) and an amount as a float.
435         * The amount is how much the target color will affect input colors, from 0f to 1f. If the target color has an
436         * alpha component that is less than 1, then amount is effectively multiplied by that alpha.
437         * @param target a libGDX color; must not be null
438         * @param amount a float that determines how much target will affect an input color; will be clamped between 0f and 1f
439         */
440        public LerpFilter(Color target, float amount) {
441            this.target = target.toFloatBits();
442            this.amount = MathUtils.clamp(amount, 0f, 1f);
443        }
444
445        /**
446         * Builds a LerpFilter with a packed float color and an amount as a float.
447         * The amount is how much the target color will affect input colors, from 0f to 1f. If the target color has an
448         * alpha component that is less than 1, then amount is effectively multiplied by that alpha.
449         * @param target a packed float color; must not be null
450         * @param amount a float that determines how much target will affect an input color; will be clamped between 0f and 1f
451         */
452
453        public LerpFilter(float target, float amount)
454        {
455            this.target = target;
456            this.amount = MathUtils.clamp(amount, 0f, 1f);
457        }
458
459        /**
460         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
461         *
462         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
463         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
464         */
465        @Override
466        public float alter(float color) {
467            return lerpFloatColorsBlended(color, target, amount);
468        }
469    }
470
471    /**
472     * A FloatFilter that linearly interpolates (lerps) any color it is given toward the most-similar of a group of
473     * given colors. Uses {@link SColor#lerpFloatColorsBlended(float, float, float)} to mix a requested color with the
474     * chosen target color, and this means the alpha of the target color affects the amount of change instead of the
475     * resulting alpha. Changing the alpha of the colors this is given can be done easily with
476     * {@link SColor#translucentColor(float, float)}, and this allows you to specify varying amounts to mix by.
477     */
478    public static class MultiLerpFilter extends FloatFilter {
479        public float[] targets;
480        public float amount;
481        /**
482         * Builds a MultiLerpFilter with an array of Color objects (which will be converted to an array of packed float
483         * colors) and an amount as a float. The amount is how much the target colors will affect input colors, from 0f
484         * to 1f. If a target color has an alpha component that is less than 1, then amount is effectively multiplied by
485         * that alpha. If you want to edit the alpha without duplicating Color objects, you can use
486         * {@link SColor#translucentColor(Color, float)} to make a float array to pass to
487         *{@link #MultiLerpFilter(float, float...)}.
488         * @param amount a float that determines how much target will affect an input color; will be clamped between 0f and 1f
489         * @param targets an array of libGDX Color objects; must not be null or empty
490         */
491        public MultiLerpFilter(float amount, Color[] targets) {
492            this.targets = new float[targets.length];
493            for (int i = 0; i < targets.length; i++) {
494                this.targets[i] = targets[i].toFloatBits();
495            }
496            this.amount = MathUtils.clamp(amount, 0f, 1f);
497        }
498
499        /**
500         * Builds a MultiLerpFilter with an array of packed float colors and an amount as a float.
501         * The amount is how much the target color will affect input colors, from 0f to 1f. If the target color has an
502         * alpha component that is less than 1, then amount is effectively multiplied by that alpha.
503         * @param amount a float that determines how much target will affect an input color; will be clamped between 0f and 1f
504         * @param targets an array or vararg of packed float colors; must not be null or empty
505         */
506
507        public MultiLerpFilter(float amount, float... targets)
508        {
509            this.targets = targets;
510            this.amount = MathUtils.clamp(amount, 0f, 1f);
511        }
512
513        /**
514         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
515         *
516         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
517         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
518         */
519        @Override
520        public float alter(float color) {
521            int choice = 0, diff = SColor.difference2(targets[0], color);
522            for (int i = 1; i < targets.length; i++) {
523                if(diff != (diff = Math.min(SColor.difference2(targets[i], color), diff)))
524                    choice = i;
525            }
526            return lerpFloatColorsBlended(color, targets[choice], amount);
527        }
528    }
529
530    /**
531     * A FloatFilter that limits the colors it can return to a fixed palette, and won't return any colors that are
532     * missing from that palette (although it can always return fully-transparent). {@link PaletteReducerFilter} is also
533     * an option; it uses more memory but is faster to look up colors in larger palettes (it has a maximum size of 256
534     * colors, though, which this class doesn't).
535     */
536    public static class PaletteFilter extends FloatFilter {
537        public float[] targets;
538        /**
539         * Builds a PaletteFilter with an array of Color objects that this will choose from. The array will be converted
540         * to an array of packed float colors, and not referenced directly.
541         * @param targets an array of libGDX Color objects; must not be null or empty
542         */
543        public PaletteFilter(final Color[] targets) {
544            this.targets = new float[targets.length];
545            for (int i = 0; i < targets.length; i++) {
546                this.targets[i] = targets[i].toFloatBits();
547            }
548        }
549
550        /**
551         * Builds a PaletteFilter with an array of packed float colors that this will choose from. The array will be
552         * referenced directly, not copied, so if you change the contents of targets, it will be reflected here.
553         * @param targets an array or vararg of packed float colors; must not be null or empty
554         */
555
556        public PaletteFilter(final float... targets)
557        {
558            this.targets = targets;
559        }
560
561        /**
562         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
563         *
564         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
565         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
566         */
567        @Override
568        public float alter(float color) {
569            if(color >= 0f) //if color is halfway-transparent or closer to transparent...
570                return 0f; // return fully transparent
571            int choice = 0, diff = SColor.difference2(targets[0], color);
572            for (int i = 1; i < targets.length; i++) {
573                if(diff != (diff = Math.min(SColor.difference2(targets[i], color), diff)))
574                    choice = i;
575            }
576            return targets[choice];
577        }
578    }
579
580    /**
581     * A FloatFilter that limits the colors it can return to a fixed palette as determined by a {@link PaletteReducer},
582     * and won't return any colors that are missing from that palette (although it can always return fully-transparent).
583     * This is like {@link PaletteFilter} but trades off memory usage (it uses about 33KB to store a large-ish lookup
584     * table) to improve speed on large palettes. This can't use a palette larger than 256 colors (including transparent
585     * almost always).
586     */
587    public static class PaletteReducerFilter extends FloatFilter {
588        public PaletteReducer reducer;
589
590        /**
591         * Builds a PaletteReducerFilter that will use the 256-color (including transparent) DawnBringer Aurora palette.
592         */
593        public PaletteReducerFilter()
594        {
595            reducer = new PaletteReducer();
596        }
597        
598        /**
599         * Builds a PaletteReducerFilter with the given PaletteReducer, which will be referenced without copying. You
600         * can call {@link PaletteReducer#exact(Color[])} or other similar methods before this filter is used to set up
601         * the palette, and this is often done before the PaletteReducer is passed here.
602         * @param palette a PaletteReducer that should have the desired palette set up before this is used
603         */
604        public PaletteReducerFilter(final PaletteReducer palette) {
605            reducer = palette;
606        }
607
608        /**
609         * Builds a PaletteReducerFilter with an array or vararg of libGDX colors (at most 256 colors, and often
610         * starting with a transparent color) that this will choose from. The array will have its contents read but will
611         * not be held onto, so later changes won't affect it.
612         * @param targets an array or vararg of libGDX colors; must not be null
613         */
614
615        public PaletteReducerFilter(final Color... targets)
616        {
617            reducer = new PaletteReducer(targets);
618        }
619
620        /**
621         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
622         *
623         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
624         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
625         */
626        @Override
627        public float alter(float color) {
628            return reducer.reduceFloat(color);
629        }
630    }
631
632    /**
633     * A FloatFilter that makes the colors requested from it highly saturated and change in strange ways.
634     * Hue is affected by the original hue, value and a timer that increments very slowly. Saturation is affected by the
635     * original hue, value and that same timer. Value is affected by the original hue, saturation, and value. It should
636     * look unreal and disorienting, like a stereotypically-psychedelic hallucination.
637     * <br>
638     * <a href="https://i.imgur.com/mzOBD0v.gif">A short recording of this can be seen here</a>.
639     */
640    public static class HallucinateFilter extends FloatFilter {
641
642        public HallucinateFilter() {
643        }
644        /**
645         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
646         *
647         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
648         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
649         */
650        @Override
651        public float alter(float color) {
652            float t = (System.currentTimeMillis() & 0xfff) * 0x1p-12f,
653                    h = hueOfFloat(color),
654                    s = saturationOfFloat(color),
655                    v = valueOfFloat(color);
656            return floatGetHSV(
657                    (v * 4f + h + t) % 1.0f,
658                    Math.max(0f, Math.min((h + v) * 0.65f + t * 0.4f, 1f)),
659                    MathExtras.clamp((h + v + s) * 0.35f + 0.7f, 0f, 1f),
660                    alphaOfFloatF(color));
661
662        }
663    }
664
665    /**
666     * Randomly changes each color requested by up to 1/8 of the full range for a channel, up or down. This changes
667     * every color independently, so two requests of the same color in the same frame could easily look different.
668     */
669    public static class WiggleFilter extends FloatFilter {
670        private long state;
671        public WiggleFilter() {
672            state = DiverRNG.determine(System.currentTimeMillis());
673        }
674        /**
675         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
676         *
677         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
678         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
679         */
680        @Override
681        public float alter(float color) {
682            int r = (int)DiverRNG.determine(++state) & 0x1F1F1F;
683            return NumberTools.intBitsToFloat((NumberTools.floatToRawIntBits(color) ^ r));
684        }
685    }
686
687}
